days_of_the_week.description: The first day of the working week, following Sunday.
The day of the week before Wednesday and following Monday.
The day of the week between Tuesday and Thursday.
The day of the week before Friday and following Wednesday.
The day of the week before Saturday and following Thursday.
The day of the week before Sunday and following Friday, part of the weekend.
The day of the week before Monday and following Saturday, part of the weekend.

months_of_the_year.description: The first month of the year, having 31 days.
The second month of the year, having 28 or 29 days.
The third month of the year, having 31 days.
The fourth month of the year, having 30 days.
The fifth month of the year, having 31 days.
The sixth month of the year, having 30 days.
The seventh month of the year, having 31 days.
The eighth month of the year, having 31 days.
The ninth month of the year, having 30 days.
The tenth month of the year, having 31 days.
The eleventh month of the year, having 30 days.
The twelfth month of the year, having 31 days.

money_matters.description: Physical money in the form of notes and coins.
A sum of money taken out of a bank account.
A plastic card from a financial company allowing the holder to purchase goods on credit.
A written order to a bank to pay a stated sum from the drawer's account.
To do something or pay for something before it is due.
A yearly charge by banks for the use of their services or products, like a credit card.
A fee paid every month to be part of a club, organization, or to receive a service.
The percentage of a sum of money charged for its use or for borrowing it.
A sum of money paid into a bank account or as a down payment on a purchase.
Money that a student pays to a university or college for their teaching.
The state of being extremely poor and lacking basic needs.
A document sent by a bank listing transactions for an account over a given period.
The process of budgeting, saving, investing, and spending financial resources.
A bank account for day-to-day transactions, allowing for deposits and withdrawals (UK term).
A type of bank account designed for people in higher education, often with benefits like no fees.
To take money out of a bank account.
An investment with a low chance of losing money, but typically offering a smaller profit.
A long-term loan from a bank to help someone buy a house.
An extra period of time allowed for payment of a debt or to meet a requirement.
A situation in which a government's, company's, or individual's expenses exceed their income.
A coupon from a store that can be exchanged for goods or a discount.
A voucher entitling the holder to a discount for a particular product.
Fake currency produced without the legal sanction of the state or government.
Money that has been collected by the state, usually through taxation.
Money that people pay in taxes, emphasizing it belongs to the people, not the government.
A sum of money that is owed or due.
A loan or purchase plan where you pay no interest for a set period.
The action of buying something, or an item that has been bought.
A repayment of only a part of the sum of money that you originally paid.
A financial product that pays out a fixed stream of payments, often used for retirement income.
Describes a payment that will not be returned in any circumstances.
A brand of credit and debit cards from a global payments technology company.
A multinational financial services corporation that facilitates electronic funds transfers.
The expenses incurred in getting a product from the manufacturer to the final customer.
Money received on a regular basis for work or through investments.
The part of an organization that manages its money and financial affairs.
The management of money and financial decisions for a household.
A shop, often at an airport, where goods are sold without the taxes that are normally added.

subjects.description: The systematic study of the physical and natural world through observation and experiment.
The activities associated with the governance of a country or area.
The study of past events, particularly in human affairs.
The scientific study of life and living organisms.
The art and science of designing and constructing buildings.
The system of rules that a particular country or community recognizes as regulating the actions of its members.
The study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere.
The study of human history through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artifacts.
Written works, especially those considered of superior or lasting artistic merit.
The coordination and organization of business activities.
The science or practice of farming, including the cultivation of soil and rearing of animals.
The science of collecting and analyzing numerical data in large quantities.
The abstract science of number, quantity, and space.
Reasoning conducted or assessed according to strict principles of validity.
The branch of science concerned with the nature and properties of matter and energy.
The scientific study of the human mind and its functions, especially those affecting behavior.
The study of human societies, cultures, and their development.
The branch of knowledge concerned with the production, consumption, and transfer of wealth.
The study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.
Art forms such as music, dance, and drama which are performed for an audience.
Art forms such as painting, drawing, and sculpture, which are primarily visual in nature.
The branch of science dealing with the identification and properties of substances.
Academic disciplines that study aspects of human society and culture.

studying_at_college.description: A document summarizing the topics, assignments, and schedule for a specific academic course.
A learning activity where students talk about a topic together to share ideas.
A document with information or exercises given to students in a class.
Any academic task submitted in written form, such as an essay or report.
The process of creating a formal document that presents information in an organized format.
A systematic investigation to establish facts and reach new conclusions.
The process of carefully checking a piece of writing for errors in spelling and grammar.
A scientific procedure undertaken to make a discovery or test a hypothesis.
Practical contact with and observation of facts or events; can also refer to work experience.
A source of information, like a book or article, cited in academic writing.
A book used as a standard work for the study of a particular subject.
A book or electronic resource that lists words and their meanings.
A portable computer suitable for use while traveling.
A machine for printing text or pictures onto paper from a computer.
A staff member who helps students with academic planning and personal concerns.
The combined, effective action of a group of people.
A self-contained unit of study in a larger course or degree program.
The subject of a text, discussion, or piece of research.
The evaluation of the quality or ability of someone or something.
A building containing collections of books and other resources for borrowing or study.
A division of a university dealing with a particular field of knowledge.
A facility with multiple computers available for students to use.
A room where a class of students is taught.
An educational talk given to an audience of students.
A teacher who instructs a single student or a very small group.
A large room used for events, lectures, and gatherings in a university.
The action of being present at a place, such as a class or lecture.
The latest time or date by which an assignment must be finished.
A formal talk given to an audience.
An official document attesting to a fact, often the completion of a short course.
A certificate awarded by an educational institution for completing a course of study.
An exam used to determine a student's existing knowledge and assign them to the correct level.
People who are studying in a country that is not their own.
Studying or working for the whole of the available or standard working day or week.
The buildings, equipment, and services provided for a particular purpose.
An educational institution or establishment, in particular one providing higher education.
A room where meals are eaten, such as a canteen or refectory in a college.
A person who is highly skilled or knowledgeable in a particular subject.
Facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education.
A place for someone to live or stay, such as student housing.
An arrangement where a student lives with a local family while studying.
A ceremony at which degrees or diplomas are awarded to students.
A long essay on a particular subject, especially one written for a university degree.
A printed sheet of paper, sometimes folded, containing information or advertising.
The teaching staff of a university or college.
People, usually children, who are taught by a teacher.
Information about reactions to a performance or piece of work, used as a basis for improvement.
Pieces of work to be done or undertaken.
The results or consequences of an action, course, or process.
Education at a university or college level.
General rules, principles, or pieces of advice.
A person who supervises a student's research, especially for a thesis or dissertation.
An undergraduate academic degree awarded by colleges and universities.
The body of words used in a particular language.
The range of services offered to help students with academic and personal issues.
A book, journal, or other piece of writing that is made available to the public.
A plan for carrying out a process or procedure, giving lists of intended events and times.
The university department responsible for student records, registration, and transcripts.
Writing materials such as paper, pens, and envelopes.

marketing.description: A publication containing a list of items for sale, often with descriptions and prices.
A formal meeting to question or consult someone, often for a job or research.
A bulletin issued periodically to the members of a society, business, or organization.
The activity of striving to gain something by defeating or establishing superiority over others.
A broadcast show on television.
Plans of action or policies designed to achieve a major or overall aim.
A specific procedure for collecting and analyzing data in a study.
The group of businesses involved in providing amusement, such as film, television, and theatre.
The action of leading a group of people or an organization.
The process of dealing with or controlling things or people.
A public showing of things for people to see, often in a store or museum.
Articles or substances that are manufactured or refined for sale.
A person who buys goods or services from a shop or business.
A discount, deal, or gift offered to customers for a limited time.
The process of gathering and measuring information on targeted variables.
A set of printed questions with a choice of answers, for a survey or statistical study.
An investigation of the opinions or experience of a group of people.
The main means of communication (e.g., television, radio) that reach large numbers of people.
A fact or piece of data obtained from a study of a large quantity of numerical data.
The difference between the selling price of a product and the cost to produce it.
The process of questioning people to get information about their opinions.
A small card printed with a person's name and business affiliation details.
The action of teaching a person a particular skill or type of behavior.
A person undergoing training for a particular job or profession.
Goods to be bought and sold.
To make something on a large scale using machinery.
The action of finding new people to join an organization or company.

nature.description: An open area of land, especially one planted with crops or pasture, typically bounded by hedges or fences.
A bridge designed solely for pedestrians.
The surroundings or conditions in which a person, animal, or plant lives or operates.
A cascade of water falling from a height, formed when a river or stream flows over a precipice or steep incline.
A large natural stream of water flowing in a channel to the sea, a lake, or another such stream.
A large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level.
A large area covered chiefly with trees and undergrowth.
A group of houses and associated buildings, larger than a hamlet and smaller than a town, situated in a rural area.
The part of the land adjoining or near the sea.
A ridge of rock, sand, or coral just above or below the surface of the sea.
A large body of water surrounded by land.
A low area between hills or mountains, typically with a river or stream flowing through it.
A naturally raised area of land, not as high or craggy as a mountain.
A steep rock face, especially at the edge of the sea.
A piece of land completely surrounded by water.
A piece of land almost surrounded by water or projecting out into a body of water.
A sudden violent shaking of the ground, causing great destruction.
A mass of snow, ice, and rocks falling rapidly down a mountainside.
A mobile, destructive vortex of violently rotating winds having the appearance of a funnel-shaped cloud.
A tropical storm in the region of the Indian or western Pacific oceans.
The process by which fertile land becomes desert, typically as a result of drought or deforestation.
A mountain or hill having a crater through which lava, rock fragments, and gas are or have been erupted from the earth's crust.
A sudden event, such as an accident or a natural catastrophe, that causes great damage or loss of life.
An event causing great and often sudden damage or suffering; a disaster.
The process of wearing away rock or soil by wind, water, or other natural agents.
The sliding down of a mass of earth or rock from a mountain or cliff.
A violent disturbance of the atmosphere with strong winds and usually rain, thunder, lightning, or snow.
An overflowing of a large amount of water beyond its normal confines, especially over what is normally dry land.
A severe storm with a violent wind, in particular a tropical cyclone in the Caribbean.
A small body of still water formed naturally or by hollowing or embanking.
An area of land overgrown with dense forest and tangled vegetation, typically in the tropics.
A fertile spot in a desert where water is found.
A barrier constructed to hold back water and raise its level, forming a reservoir used to generate electricity or as a water supply.
A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it.

health.description: A discipline involving specific postures and breathing control for health and relaxation.
A Chinese martial art involving very slow, controlled movements.
To stay physically healthy through regular exercise.
A self-service counter or table where customers can create their own salads.
A person who does not eat meat or fish.
Leisure pursuits undertaken in the open air.
Time when one is not working; free time.
A disorder of structure or function; an illness or sickness.
An occasion when food is eaten, or the food itself.
An essential nutrient found in foods like meat, cheese, and eggs.
A diet providing adequate amounts of all necessary nutrients for good health.
A diagram representing the optimal number of servings from various food groups.
An organic compound essential for normal growth and nutrition.
A major source of energy found in foods like bread, pasta, and rice.
A grain widely cultivated as a staple food, especially in Asia.
A food made from wheat dough, formed into various shapes like spaghetti or macaroni.
A starchy plant tuber eaten as a vegetable.
An Italian dish of a flat, round base of dough baked with toppings.
A glossy red fruit, commonly eaten as a vegetable.
A staple food made from flour, water, and yeast, mixed together and baked.
Grains used for food, such as wheat or corn, or a breakfast food made from them.
Inorganic substances, like calcium or iron, needed by the human body for good health.
A chemical element and essential trace mineral for human health.
The flesh of an animal, typically a mammal or bird, as food.
Shellfish and sea fish served as food.
An oval object laid by female birds, often eaten as food.
An edible seed, growing in long pods on certain leguminous plants.
A white fluid from female mammals for nourishing their young, often from a cow.
A food made from the pressed curds of milk.
A semi-solid food prepared from milk fermented by added bacteria.
The sweet, fleshy product of a tree or plant that contains seeds.
A plant or part of a plant used as food.
Fruits like oranges, lemons, and grapefruit, known for their acidity.
The unripe fruit of a sweet pepper, eaten as a vegetable.
A small, round, edible black berry used in drinks and desserts.
A fruit consisting of a hard shell around an edible kernel.
The yellow internal part of an egg, rich in protein and fat.
A large organ in the abdomen which can also be eaten as food.
A drug or other preparation for the treatment or prevention of disease.
Medical care given to a patient for an illness or injury.
A medicine or treatment for a disease or injury.
The care of patients provided by a qualified nurse.
A place where young children are cared for during the day.
Physical activity performed consistently to improve health and fitness.

the_environment.description: The trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's lower atmosphere due to certain gases.
Rainfall made acidic by atmospheric pollution that causes environmental harm.
The long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period.
A colorless, odorless gas produced by burning carbon and organic compounds, and by respiration (CO2).
The combustion of materials like coal, oil, and natural gas to produce energy, releasing CO2.
Gases ejected from an engine as waste products.
The action of clearing a wide area of trees.
A gas that contributes to the formation of smog and acid rain.
Fog or haze combined with smoke and other atmospheric pollutants.
The weather conditions prevailing in an area in general or over a long period.
The presence of harmful substances or contaminants in the environment.
The degree of heat present in a substance or object.
Industrial facilities for the generation of electric power.
A place to dispose of waste material by burying it and covering it over with soil.
Large ruminant animals with horns and cloven hoofs, domesticated for meat or milk.
A large wheel-like machine that is turned by the wind to produce electricity.
Power obtained by harnessing the energy of the sun's rays.
Electricity generated by using the energy of moving water.
A source of energy that is not depleted when used, such as wind or solar power.
The origin from which power can be obtained.
Consistently good in quality or performance; able to be trusted.
Devices that convert light into electricity.
Not harmful to the environment.
A chemical element that is a colorless, odorless reactive gas, essential for respiration.
Containing no synthetic or artificial additives.
A barren or desolate area, especially one with little or no vegetation.
The process in which the quality of something is damaged or destroyed.
Plants found in a particular area or habitat.
The average level of the surface of the ocean.
Continuous, directed movements of seawater generated by a number of forces.
A product which is added to soil to improve its physical qualities.
A black or dark brown rock consisting mainly of carbonized plant matter, used as a fuel.
Natural fuels such as coal or gas, formed from the remains of living organisms.
Wood that is burnt as fuel.
A prolonged period of abnormally low rainfall, leading to a shortage of water.
Made impure by exposure to or addition of a poisonous or polluting substance.

the_animal_kingdom.description: Birds that hunt and kill other animals for food, such as eagles and hawks.
Birds that are adapted to life within a marine environment.
Domesticated birds kept for eggs or meat, and wild animals hunted for food.
Warm-blooded vertebrates distinguished by the possession of hair or fur and the secretion of milk by females.
A marine mammal of the order Cetacea, such as a whale, dolphin, or porpoise.
A very large marine mammal with a streamlined hairless body and a horizontal tail fin.
A group of mammals that includes monkeys, apes, and humans.
Mammals of an order distinguished by strong gnawing incisor teeth, such as rats, mice, and squirrels.
A limbless cold-blooded vertebrate animal with gills and fins, living wholly in water.
A cold-blooded vertebrate that lives on both land and in water, such as a frog.
A cold-blooded vertebrate of a class that includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, and turtles.
A small arthropod animal that has six legs and generally one or two pairs of wings.
A sea animal that has a soft body and eight long arms.
A principal taxonomic category that ranks above class and below kingdom.
A major taxonomic rank below phylum and above order.
A taxonomic rank used in the classification of organisms, below class and above family.
A taxonomic rank between order and genus.
A taxonomic rank that is below family and above species.
A group of living organisms consisting of similar individuals capable of exchanging genes.
Farm animals regarded as an asset.
An animal, as distinct from a human being.
A large cat of Africa and India that has a tawny coat and a shaggy mane in the male.
A large flightless seabird of the southern hemisphere, with black and white plumage.

plants.description: A fungal growth that typically takes the form of a domed cap on a stalk, often used in cooking.
A group of spore-producing organisms that feed on organic matter, including molds, yeast, and mushrooms.
The main organs of photosynthesis in most plants, typically a flat, green structure.
A plant's unit of reproduction, from which a new plant can grow.
The tough central part of certain fruits, like an apple, which contains the seeds.
The tough, protective outer layer of the trunk and branches of a tree.
The main woody stem of a tree, as distinct from its branches and roots.
A very small, thin branch of a tree or shrub.
A part of a tree which grows out from the trunk or a bough.
The part of a plant that blossoms and is often colorful, involved in reproduction.
The main stalk of a plant that supports the leaves and flowers.
The part of a plant that attaches it to the ground, absorbing water and nutrients.
A group of similar things, such as flowers or fruits, growing closely together.
A substance added to soil to increase its fertility and help plants grow.

continents.description: A continent in the Western Hemisphere, mostly in the Southern Hemisphere.
A continent in the Northern Hemisphere and almost entirely within the Western Hemisphere.
The world's second-largest continent, located south of Europe.
The largest and most populous continent on Earth, located primarily in the Eastern Hemisphere.
A continent that is part of the landmass of Eurasia, west of Asia.
The smallest continent, which is also a country, located in Oceania.
The Earth's southernmost continent, an ice-covered landmass containing the South Pole.

countries.description: A transcontinental country spanning the northeast corner of Africa and southwest corner of Asia.
A country in the southern portion of North America, known for its rich history and culture.
A country in Western Europe, famous for its art, cuisine, and landmarks like the Eiffel Tower.
A country in Southeast Asia, made up of thousands of volcanic islands.
A transcontinental country located mainly on the Anatolian Peninsula in Western Asia.
A country that is part of the United Kingdom, home to London and the River Thames.
A large country in Central Europe known for its engineering, automotive industry, and forests.
A country in East Asia, the world's most populous nation.
A country in Southeast Europe with thousands of islands, known as the birthplace of democracy.
The largest country in South America, famous for its Amazon rainforest and Carnival festival.
A vast country in South Asia with diverse terrain, from Himalayan peaks to Indian Ocean coastline.
A country in East Asia constituting the northern part of the Korean Peninsula.
A Southeast Asian country known for its beaches, rainforests, and mix of cultural influences.
An island country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean, known for its dramatic landscapes.
A country in West Africa on the Gulf of Guinea, the most populous country in Africa.
A country in South Asia, home to several ancient cultures, including the Indus Valley Civilization.
A sovereign island city-state in maritime Southeast Asia, known for its cleanliness and modernity.
A mountainous Central European country, known for its ski resorts, hiking trails, and banking industry.
An island nation in northwestern Europe, made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
A country in Southern Europe, renowned for its art, fashion, cuisine, and Roman ruins.
A Caribbean nation that shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti to the west.
An archipelagic country in Southeast Asia, consisting of about 7,641 islands.
A Scandinavian country in Northern Europe, known for its high quality of life and design.

languages.description: The scientific study of language and its structure.
A person who is able to speak two languages fluently.
A person who is able to speak three languages fluently.
A person who knows and is able to use several languages.
The official language of Portugal and Brazil.
The standard and official form of the Chinese language.
The official language of Bangladesh, also known as Bangla.
The group of languages used by the people of China.
An official language of India, widely spoken in the northern part of the country.
The official language of Germany, Austria, and Liechtenstein.
The language of the Punjab region in India and Pakistan.
The official language of Iran, also known as Farsi.
The national language of the Philippines.
The official language of France and many other countries including Canada and Switzerland.
The official language of Greece and Cyprus.

homes.description: A house that is joined to another house on only one side.
A residential building divided into two separate homes with a shared wall.
A house built as part of a continuous row in a uniform style, sharing side walls.
A tall, narrow house with multiple floors, typically in a row in a city.
One of a series of houses situated side by side and sharing common walls.
A house with only one storey (level), sometimes with rooms in the roof space.
A small, traditional house, typically in the countryside, with a roof made of straw or reeds.
A large house-like trailer that is used as a permanent home.
A boat that is or can be used as a residence.
A large building containing multiple apartments (common term in the UK).
A large building containing multiple apartments (common term in the US).
An apartment building where each unit is individually owned.
A vertical pipe that carries smoke from a fireplace out of a building.
A room used for sleeping.
The floor of a building that is partly or entirely below ground level.
A person who rents out property to a tenant.
A person who pays rent to occupy a property owned by someone else.
A regular payment made by a tenant to a landlord for the use of a property.
A legal contract for renting property for a specified period.
A district or community within a town or city.
A residential area on the outskirts of a city.
A long upholstered seat with a back and arms for two or more people.
A low table placed in front of a sofa.
A large bedroom for many people, such as in a school or university.
A level of a building; a floor.
A room equipped for preparing and cooking food.
An appliance that uses cooling technology to preserve food.
An electric oven that heats food using electromagnetic radiation.
The floor of a building at or nearest to ground level.
An enclosed compartment in a cooker used for baking or roasting.
A corridor or passage inside a building.
A policy that provides financial protection against specified loss or damage.

architecture_and_buildings.description: A rounded vault forming the roof of a building, typically with a circular base.
The official residence of a sovereign, president, or other exalted personage.
A fortified building or strategic position.
A large building, typically of the medieval period, fortified against attack.
A building with glass sides and a glass roof for growing plants.
A monumental structure with a square or triangular base and sloping sides that meet in a point at the top, especially one built of stone in ancient Egypt.
A small house made from logs.
A tower containing a strong light to guide or warn ships at sea.
A small, simple single-story building or shelter.
A very tall building with many stories.
The art of making two- or three-dimensional representative or abstract forms, especially by carving stone or wood.

in_the_city.description: Large and important towns where many people live and work.
A public road in a city, town, or village, typically with houses and buildings on one or both sides.
A narrow road, especially in a rural area, or a division of a road marked for a single line of vehicles.
The central part or main business and commercial area of a city.
The main railway station in a city or large town.
An area or building where cars or other vehicles may be left temporarily.
A large shop stocking many varieties of goods in different departments.
A structure carrying a road or railway across a river, valley, or another road.
A building devoted to the worship of a god, gods, or other objects of religious reverence.
The official residence or offices of an ambassador in a foreign country.
The network of all roads in a particular area.
An institution providing medical and surgical treatment and nursing care for sick or injured people.
A public park or a large, well-kept area of land used for recreation.
A broad road in a town or city, typically having trees at regular intervals along its sides.

workplaces.description: A place or hospital department where outpatients are given medical treatment or advice.
A person qualified to treat the diseases and conditions that affect the teeth and gums.
The area in an office or hotel where visitors arrive and are greeted.
An arrangement to meet someone at a particular time and place.
The process of choosing the right people to work for an organization.
A person with whom one works in a profession or business.
A meeting for discussion or practical work on a particular subject.
A room used to display goods for sale, such as cars or furniture.
A place in a public building, such as a library or airport, where you can get information.
A person or organization that pays people to work for them.
The state of having paid work.
Without a paid job but available to work.
Collaboration between countries or organizations in the field of technology and skills.
People who provide guidance and instruction to a working group.
A state of mental or emotional strain resulting from demanding circumstances.
The power or capacity to do something.
The ability to think about or plan the future with imagination and wisdom.
The feeling or belief that one can rely on someone or something; firm trust.
A person who works for another person or a company for wages or a salary.
A temporary position with an emphasis on on-the-job training.

rating_and_qualities.description: Fair and sensible; acceptable or not too expensive.
Fulfilling expectations or needs; acceptable but not outstanding.
Able or likely to cause harm, injury, or risk.
Protected from or not exposed to danger or risk.
Advised or suggested with great confidence.
Of a low or inferior standard; not well made.
Feeling content or pleased with a result or situation.
Sad or displeased because hopes or expectations were not fulfilled.
Achieving maximum productivity with minimum wasted effort or expense.
Extremely comfortable, elegant, or enjoyable, often at great expense.
Having a color or colors, as opposed to being black, white, or neutral.
Marked or decorated with round dots or spots.
Marked with long, narrow bands of a different color or texture.

touring.description: A tour of a place or area with an expert leader or guide.
A place where tickets for public transport or entertainment are sold.
An item kept as a reminder of a person, place, or event.
A journey or excursion, especially for pleasure.
A person who is staying at a hotel or visiting another person or place.
An arrangement to have something (like a room, table, or seat) held for your use.
The scenery or prospect that can be seen from a particular place.
The customs, arts, and achievements of a particular nation, people, or group.
Worth remembering or easily remembered because of being special or unusual.
A hotel room intended for one person to stay in.
A hotel room intended for two people, often with one large bed.
An occasion when a packed meal is eaten outdoors, especially during an outing.
A place of interest that tourists visit for its natural or cultural value.
An establishment providing inexpensive accommodation, often in shared dormitories.
A set of connected rooms in a hotel, used as a single unit of accommodation.
A building containing tanks of live fish and other aquatic animals.

verbs.description: To teach a particular skill or type of behavior through practice and instruction.
To grow or cause to grow and become more mature, advanced, or elaborate.
To bring or gather together things, typically as a hobby or for study.
To observe and direct the work of a person or the execution of a task.
To make a visible sign on something; or to assess a piece of work.
To prepare written material for publication by correcting or modifying it.
To re-examine and make alterations or corrections to something.
To publicly display a work of art or item of interest in a gallery or museum.
To give money or goods for a good cause, for example to a charity.
To exceed or be greater than something else.
To enter or record on an official list or directory.
To give assistance to, especially financially; to enable to function or act.
To pursue and kill a wild animal for sport or food.
To cause someone to do something through reasoning or argument.
To focus all of one's attention on a particular object or activity.
To talk about something with another person or a group of people.
To put forward for consideration.
To put things in a neat, attractive, or required order.
To take and use something belonging to someone else with the intention of returning it.
To come to live permanently in a foreign country.
To examine or assess something formally with the possibility of instituting change.
To gain knowledge or skill in something by study, experience, or being taught.
To come into or be in physical contact with.

adjectives.description: Showing or involving great activity or vitality.
Relating to society or its organization; needing companionship.
Belonging to the very distant past and no longer in existence.
Required to be done, achieved, or present; needed.
Extraordinarily good or attractive.
Causing great enthusiasm and eagerness.
Extraordinary, especially in being attractive or enjoyable.
Lacking interest or excitement; boring.
Providing physical ease and relaxation.
Fitting in well with a person's needs, activities, and plans.
Right or appropriate for a particular person, purpose, or situation.
Inexpensive; reasonably priced.
Done, given, or acting of one's own free will.
Required by law or rules; compulsory.
Required by law or a rule; obligatory.
Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.
Lasting or intended to last or remain unchanged indefinitely.
Extremely large or great, especially in scale or degree.
Of very great extent or quantity; immense.
Tasting of, containing, or preserved with salt.
No longer in existence; having no living members.
Susceptible to physical or emotional attack or harm.
Tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen.
Hopeful and confident about the future.
Having or showing a sensible and practical idea of what can be achieved.
Concerned with the actual doing or use of something rather than with theory and ideas.
Intelligent and well informed.
Able to be easily modified to respond to altered circumstances; adaptable.
Feeling or showing certainty about something; self-assured.
Living in or originating from the west, particularly Europe or the Americas.
Concentrated on a single area or subject; very thorough or vigorous.
Free from disturbance; calm.
Beautiful in a dramatic and eye-catching way.
Not damaged or impaired in any way; complete.
Different from one another; of different kinds or sorts.

hobbies.description: A sport where participants navigate between points in unfamiliar terrain using a map and compass.
The recreational pastime of exploring wild cave systems.
The hobby or practice of exploring caves, especially as a recreational activity.
The sport or skill of shooting with a bow and arrows, especially at a target.
The activity of gliding over a surface of ice on skates.
The sport of swimming underwater using self-contained underwater breathing apparatus.
Swimming through water while equipped with a diving mask and a breathing tube (snorkel).
The sport of riding and performing tricks on a skateboard.
A sport where the objective is to roll biased balls so they stop close to a smaller ball.
An indoor game where small pointed missiles are thrown at a circular target.
A game played on an outdoor course, striking a small ball with clubs into a series of holes.
A game played with cues on a cloth-covered table, driving balls into pockets.
The art or process of taking and processing photographs.
The practice of applying paint or pigment to a surface like a canvas to create an image.
The craft of making pots, dishes, and other objects from clay.
The art of shaping objects from wood by carving with a sharp tool.
The activity of tending and cultivating a garden as a pastime.
The hobby of collecting postage stamps and related items.
The craft of decorating fabric or other materials using a needle to apply thread or yarn.
The sport or activity of ascending steep rock faces or mountains.
A board game of strategic skill for two players, played on a checkered board.
The activity of jumping from an aircraft using a large fabric canopy to descend slowly.

sports.description: A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players on a circular field.
A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of nine players on a diamond-shaped field.
A game where two teams of five players try to score points by shooting a ball through a high hoop.
A team game played with an oval ball that can be carried, passed, and kicked.
A team game where players kick a round ball into the opposing team's goal.
A team game played with an oval ball on a rectangular field with goalposts.
A team game played with curved sticks and a small hard ball or puck.
The sport of moving through water by using one's limbs.
A racket sport where players hit a ball over a net into an opponent's court.
An indoor racket sport played by hitting a small rubber ball against a walled court.
A racket sport using a shuttlecock, which is hit back and forth over a high net.
An indoor game where players hit a lightweight ball back and forth across a table with a net.
A large venue with tiers of seats for spectators at sporting events.
A group of players forming one side in a competitive game.
A track and field event in which an athlete throws a heavy circular plate.
A track and field event where a light spear is thrown for distance.
A track and field event where a heavy metal ball on a wire is thrown for distance.
A track and field event in which competitors jump over a horizontal bar.
The sport of racing horses, often with betting involved.
The competitive sport of riding horses over a course of obstacles.
A team sport played on horseback, where the objective is to score goals against an opposing team.
The sport or activity of riding a bicycle.
A large room or building equipped for physical exercise and sports.
A person who is highly skilled in sports and physical exercise.
Sports characterized by high speed and a high level of risk.
The sport of flying using a wide, rectangular, steerable parachute.
The sport of jumping from an aircraft and falling for as long as safely possible before opening a parachute.
The sport of descending a vertical surface, such as a cliff or wall, by a rope.
The sport of sliding down a snow-covered slope on a single board.
The sport of leaping from a high place while secured by a long elastic cord.
The sport of riding on the forward-moving face of a wave, usually on a surfboard.
A water sport that combines elements of surfing and sailing on a sailboard.
The sport of riding a small, self-propelled vehicle on water.
The activity of navigating a river with rough, turbulent water in an inflatable raft.
A water sport where a person rides on a small surfboard, propelled across the water by a large kite.
The sport of riding bicycles off-road, often over rough terrain.
Running at a steady, gentle pace as a form of exercise.
An exercise in which a person raises and lowers their body with their arms while lying face down.
A piece of exercise equipment consisting of a long bar with weights at each end.
An exercise machine for walking or running on a continuously moving belt.
A modern Japanese martial art and combat sport.
Activities done for enjoyment when one is not working.
A cue sport played on a large table with 15 red balls and 6 balls of other colors.
A competition to find the best player or team in a particular sport.
The sport of paddling a light, narrow boat, especially for recreation or competition.
A light snack or drink provided during a break in an event.

shapes.description: A plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles.
A four-sided flat shape with straight sides and four right angles.
Shaped like a triangle; having three sides and three angles.
A plane figure with at least three straight sides and angles.
Having a rounded and slightly elongated outline, like that of an egg.
Shaped like a sphere; round like a ball.
A curve which winds outwards from a central point.
Having the form of a circle; round.
Having a bend or turn from a straight line; not straight.
Having the shape of a cylinder; straight sides and a circular cross-section.

measurement.description: The measurement or extent of something from side to side.
The measurement of something from end to end.
The height of an object or point in relation to sea level or ground level.
A system of weights and measures originally developed in England (e.g., inches, pounds, gallons).
A decimal measuring system based on the meter, liter, and gram.
A measure of the amount of matter in an object.
The distance from the top or surface down to the bottom of something.
The distance or measurement from side to side of something; another word for width.
The measurement of someone or something from base to top.
The property of space that has length, width, and depth.
The rate at which something occurs or is repeated over a particular period of time.

transportations.description: An aircraft designed specifically to carry freight rather than passengers.
The action of transporting goods, or the goods being transported.
A large cargo ship designed to carry goods in standard-sized containers.
A vessel for travel on water, propelled by oars, sails, or an engine.
A small boat kept on a ship for use in an emergency, or one used to save people at sea.
A boat for conveying passengers and goods over a relatively short distance as a regular service.
A vehicle that travels over land or water on a cushion of air.
A boat with wing-like foils that lift it out of the water at high speed.
A large passenger ship, especially one that makes regular long-distance voyages.
A long, narrow boat specifically designed for use on canals.
A specific type of canal boat, typically with a maximum width of 7 feet.
The activity of sailing in a small, open sailboat.
A boat propelled primarily by wind using sails.
A steam-powered ship propelled by one or more large paddle wheels.
A motorboat with a cabin for accommodation.
A small boat that is moved through the water by using oars.
A small boat propelled by rowing.
A small canoe-like boat where the paddler sits and uses a double-bladed paddle.
A narrow, light boat moved by one or more paddlers using single-bladed paddles.
A long, narrow boat with a flat bottom, propelled by pushing a long pole against the river bed.
A traditional, flat-bottomed Venetian rowing boat, used on the canals of Venice.
Any machine capable of flight, such as a plane or helicopter.
An aircraft that gets lift from a set of horizontally revolving blades.
An aircraft with floats or a hull, allowing it to land on or take off from water.
A large, steerable, powered aircraft that is lighter than air, such as a blimp or zeppelin.
A large bag filled with heated air, with a basket for passengers, that rises and travels in the air.
A place where aircraft regularly take off and land, with facilities for passengers.
The group of people who work on and operate a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
A traveler on a public or private conveyance other than the pilot, driver, or crew.
A raised level surface at a train station from which passengers can board a train.
To pay money to borrow a car for a short period of time.
A road vehicle, typically with four wheels, powered by an engine or electric motor.

vehicles.description: A bus with two floors or levels.
A bus with only one floor or level.
A small bus used for transporting a few people.
A bus used to transport children to and from school, often yellow in color.
A comfortable bus used for longer journeys or tours.
A large, heavy motor vehicle used for transporting goods, materials, or troops.
A vehicle designed to carry liquids or gases in bulk.
A medium-sized vehicle used for transporting goods or a group of people.
The British English term for a large, heavy motor vehicle for transporting goods.
A large vehicle designed specifically to carry other vehicles.
A small industrial vehicle with a power-operated pronged platform for lifting and moving heavy loads.
A vehicle used to pull other vehicles that have broken down.
The British English term for a vehicle that tows other vehicles.
A small truck with an enclosed cab and an open cargo area in the back.
A sturdy car with four-wheel drive, suitable for rough terrain.
A vehicle equipped for living in, towed by a car and used for vacations.
A motor vehicle, often a van, that is equipped for living in while traveling.
A powerful motor vehicle with large rear wheels, used on farms for pulling machinery.
A car, with a driver, that you pay to take you to a destination.
A common synonym for a taxi.
A public transport vehicle, usually powered by electricity, that runs on rails in the street.
The British term for a system of electric trains running in tunnels below a city.
The American term for an underground electric railway.
A train that is powered by a steam engine.
A train that carries goods in bulk rather than passengers.
The British English term for a train that carries freight.

weather.description: Having a high level of water vapor in the atmosphere.
Having a high degree of heat or a high temperature.
Describing weather that is hot and unpleasantly humid.
Of or at a low or relatively low temperature.
Of or at a fairly low temperature; pleasantly cold.
Filled or covered with fine particles of dry earth or other matter.
Extremely cold; below the temperature at which water turns to ice (0°C or 32°F).
Of or at a fairly or comfortably high temperature.
Marked by or having a high level of rainfall.
A prediction of what the weather will be like in the near future.
A device for receiving broadcast signals, often used for weather stations.
Water or other liquid diffused in a small quantity as vapor or condensation.

places.description: A public building with collections of books and media for people to read or borrow.
An artificial structure filled with water for the purpose of swimming or other water recreation.
A restaurant where customers serve themselves from a counter and pay before eating.
A small, simple house, typically one in a rural or semi-rural location.
The building where the highest legislative body of a country meets.
A room, group of rooms, or building in which someone may live or stay.
A place where people pay to sit and eat meals that are cooked and served on the premises.
A restaurant provided by an organization such as a college or factory for its staff.
A small, informal establishment selling light meals, snacks, and drinks.
A store where books are sold.
A building that has facilities for various sports, such as a swimming pool or courts.
The governing body of a municipality or city.
A room or building specifically designed for dancers to practice or be taught.
A large public garden or area of land used for recreation.
A group that meets to practice speaking a language or for general discussion.
A school or class that prepares children for first grade.

equipment_and_tools.description: A hard or padded protective hat, worn to protect the head from injury.
An object constructed or adapted to make musical sounds.
A sealed plastic unit containing a length of audiotape, videotape, film, etc.
A tiny piece of silicon carrying a complex electronic circuit; a microchip.
An electronic visual display for computers or other devices.
A small mechanical or electronic device or tool, especially an ingenious or novel one.
A thing made or adapted for a particular purpose, especially a piece of mechanical or electronic equipment.
A flat panel on an electronic device on which images and data are displayed.
A device for slowing or stopping a moving vehicle, typically by applying pressure to the wheels. (Note: often spelled 'brakes' in this context).
Circular objects that revolve on an axle and are fixed below a vehicle to enable it to move.
A pencil with a replaceable and mechanically extendable solid pigment core called a 'lead'.
A flat, thin circular object used for storing electronic data.
A bag with shoulder straps which allow it to be carried on one's back.

the_arts_and_media.description: A dramatic work in one or more acts, set to music for singers and instrumentalists.
A large group of musicians who play many different instruments together.
A live music performance in front of an audience.
An elaborate musical composition for a full orchestra.
The people (such as reporters and photographers) who work for newspapers, magazines, etc.
A person who directs the performance of an orchestra or choir.
A singer, especially one who sings with a pop band.
The assembled spectators or listeners at a public event, such as a play or concert.
An organized series of concerts, plays, or films, typically held annually.
A public festival involving processions, music, dancing, and the use of masquerade.
A public display of works of art or other items of interest, held in a gallery or museum.
Music written in the European tradition during a period lasting approximately from 1730 to 1820.
A building or outdoor area in which plays and other dramatic performances are given.
A place where films are shown to the public.
A room or building for the display or sale of works of art.
A building housing objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest.
An artistic dance form performed to music using precise and highly formalized steps.
A system for transmitting visual images and sound that are reproduced on screens.
The transmission of sound programs to the public by radio waves.
Visual images or designs on some surface, such as a screen, to inform or entertain.
A printed publication containing news, articles, advertisements, and correspondence.

materials.description: The thick, soft hair that covers the bodies of some animals.
A solid, typically hard, shiny, malleable material that is a good electrical and thermal conductor.
A hard, strong alloy of iron with carbon, widely used in construction and for making tools.
A lightweight, silver-white metallic element.
A red-brown metal, often used for electrical wiring and pipes.
A tough, elastic substance made from the latex of a tropical plant or synthetically.
A synthetic material made from a wide range of organic polymers that can be molded into shape.
Hard, brittle, heat-resistant materials made by shaping and firing a nonmetallic mineral, such as clay.
A hard, brittle, transparent substance made by fusing sand with soda and lime.
A powder that sets to a hard material when mixed with water, used as a binder in concrete.
Hard, solid, non-metallic mineral matter of which rock is made.
A type of cloth or woven fabric.
A soft white fibrous substance used as textile fiber.
Cloth or other material produced by weaving or knitting fibers.
The fine, soft, curly hair forming the fleece of a sheep or similar animal.
A material made from the tanned skin of an animal.
The hard, whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
Material in thin sheets made from the pulp of wood, used for writing or printing.
Timber that has been sawn into rough planks or boards.
The hard, fibrous material forming the main substance of a tree's trunk or branches.
An adhesive substance used for sticking objects or materials together.
A material made from two or more different materials which remain separate in the resulting structure.
A reinforced plastic material composed of glass fibers embedded in a resin matrix.
A building material made from a mixture of gravel, sand, cement, and water.
A sticky, yellowish substance secreted by bees or created synthetically.
A precious, shiny, greyish-white metallic element.
A yellow, precious metal, used in jewelry and for coinage.
Any of the flat, lightweight structures growing from a bird's skin.

works_and_jobs.description: A person's job or principal activity.
A paid occupation, especially one that involves prolonged training and a formal qualification.
A person who plans the form or look of something before it is made.
A person who paints the inside of houses or applies wallpaper.
A person who designs buildings and supervises their construction.
A person who designs, builds, or maintains engines, machines, or public works.
A person responsible for controlling or administering an organization or group of staff.
A woman who serves food and drinks at tables in a restaurant or cafe.
A man who serves food and drinks at tables in a restaurant or cafe.
A person who teaches, especially in a school.
An unoccupied position or job.
A university academic of the highest rank.
A person who concentrates primarily on a particular subject or activity.
An expert in the study of the human mind and behavior.
A person who freely offers to take part in an enterprise or undertake a task without pay.
Working for different companies at different times rather than being permanently employed by one company.
A person employed to assist with correspondence, keep records, and make appointments.
A person who is highly skilled in a particular craft.
Practical experience of a particular job, gained while working in that job.
A brief account of a person's education, qualifications, and previous jobs.
The address to which a person's mail is sent.
A person who greets visitors and deals with inquiries in an office or hotel.
A person who operates the flying controls of an aircraft.
A person who keeps watch or protects a person or place.
An airline employee who serves passengers during a flight.
A person who gives talks or academic courses at a university or college.
A person who performs various administrative and clerical tasks in an office.
A person employed in an office or bank to keep records and accounts.
A person whose job is to keep or inspect financial accounts.
A person handling payments and receipts in a store, bank, or other business.
The person in command of a ship or aircraft.

color.description: The color of the sky on a clear day or the deep sea.
The color of fresh snow, milk, or salt; the lightest color.
A secondary color between yellow and red, like the fruit of the same name.
The color of growing grass or leaves on a tree.
A color between black and white, like that of ash or lead. (Also spelled 'gray').
The darkest color, the result of the absence or complete absorption of light.
The color of blood or a ripe strawberry.
The color of lemons, a sunflower, or gold.
A color intermediate between blue and red, often associated with royalty.
The color of soil, wood, or chocolate.
A pale red color, often associated with flowers like roses.

expressions_and_time.description: An action or event that happens on three separate occasions.
An event or activity that occurs three times within a seven-day period.
A period, typically a year, taken by a student as a break between school and university.
Working or studying for the standard number of hours in a week.
Working or studying for fewer than the standard number of hours in a week.
The middle of the day; noon.
Twelve o'clock at night; the middle of the night.
A period of one thousand years.
A period of one hundred years.

other.description: A small photograph of a person's face, used for official identification.
A nation or territory considered as an organized political community under one government.
The group of people with the authority to govern a country or state.
A single human being as distinct from a group.
The quality of being different or diverse; the absence of uniformity.
The part of the national economy that is not under direct state control.
The actual application or use of an idea, belief, or method.
The state of being male or female, especially in a social or cultural context.
The use of imagination or original ideas to create something.
The first people to live in a particular area.
Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
A public meeting or march protesting against something.
A refusal to work organized by employees as a form of protest.
An opening, such as a door or gate, that allows access to a place.
A roughly circular line, route, or movement that starts and finishes at the same place.
A formal promise or assurance that certain conditions will be fulfilled.
A conversation between two or more people.
The activity of buying and selling, especially on a large scale.
A vehicle with four wheels pulled by horses, used for transporting people.
A spoken or written account of connected events; a story.
A food made from roasted and ground cacao seeds, typically sweet.
An artificial body placed in orbit around the earth or another planet.
A conclusion or resolution reached after consideration.
A first or preliminary version of a device from which other forms are developed.
A settled way of thinking or feeling about someone or something.
The usual series of things that you do at a particular time each day.
A feeling of deep satisfaction from achieving one's potential or desires.
The condition in which things are happening or being done.
A person or thing that receives or is awarded something.
Sound waves with high frequencies, often used in medical imaging.
Measures to prevent injuries to people walking, especially from vehicles.
A long line of vehicles that cannot move or can only move very slowly.
An established or official way of doing something.
The action or process of bringing something into existence.
A thing given as a reward to the winner of a competition.
Relating to younger or less experienced people.
Relating to older or more experienced people.
A time or set of circumstances that makes it possible to do something.
An official document permitting a person to operate a motor vehicle.
A series of actions or steps taken in order to achieve a particular end.
Concerning the writing, study, or content of literature.
Made or caused by human beings, as opposed to occurring naturally.
Supporters of a republic system of government; a major political party in the USA.
A device used as protection against rain or sun.
Changed or revised often and at short intervals.
A list of people who have requested something that is not immediately available.
A network of pipes that convey wastewater for treatment.
A democracy where individual rights and freedoms are officially protected.
Advocates of democracy; a major political party in the USA.
A calendar based on the monthly cycles of the Moon's phases.
An advocate for minimal government interference in personal lives.
A patty of minced meat, fried or grilled and served in a bun.
Recordings of moving visual images.
The protection of animals, plants, and natural resources.
The average period that a person may expect to live.
An event held to generate financial support for a cause.
A piece of iron that can attract other iron-containing objects.
A form of a language that is specific to a region or social group.
A complex or unwelcome consequence of an action or event.
Extending uniformly in one direction only; without a curve.
An act of parting or of marking a departure.
The health, happiness, and fortunes of a person or group.
A book or set of books with information on many subjects, arranged alphabetically.
The process by which organisms develop and diversify from earlier forms.
A forcible overthrow of a government or social order for a new system.
The inability to read or write.
A machine capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.
A high degree of skill; expertise.
Enough to meet the needs of a situation; adequate.
